document.masterDocTitle: Taxonomic studies on the genus Sanicula (Apiaceae) from China (I): The identity of S. orthacantha var. pumila and S. pengshuiensis

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Taxonomic studies on the genus Sanicula (Apiaceae) from China (I): The identity of S. orthacantha var. pumila and S. pengshuiensis

.

=
Sanicula pengshuiensis Sheh & Liu (1991: 469)
,
syn . nov .

Type :— CHINA , Chongqing , Pengshui , Hanjia town ,
500 m
,
April 11 1979
,
S.X.Tan 106
( holotype SM715005741!, isotypes NAS00082800!, SM715005739!). Fig. 7A, B
.

Description :—Perennial. Rhizome short, woody, bearing fibrous roots, occasionally with nodes. Stems slender and erect, few branched above the middle, 8‒40 cm tall. Basal leaves 3‒30, long petiolate; petioles (2‒)5‒20(‒28) cm long; blade glabrous on both surfaces, sometimes purplish red abaxially, (0.8‒) 2‒7 cm long, (1.5‒) 4‒15 cm broad, cordatesuborbicular, ternate, segments distinctly petiolate, the median segments cuneate-obovate to rhombic, obtuse to acute and more or less trilobed at the apex, the lateral segments oblique, bilobed to the middle or only notched or rarely entire, the margins crenate-serrate with spinose teeth. Upper stem leaves reduced, 1 or 2, trisect or undivided, bractlike, linear-lanceolate to obovate-lanceolate, ca. 5 mm long, shortly petiolate or sessile. Inflorescence 1- or 2- to severalbranched; involucrate bracts 3‒6, trisect or linear-lanceolate, ca. 2 mm long; rays of the umbels 1‒7, ca. 3.5 mm long; involucellate bracteoles 4‒6, linear to lanceolate, ca. 0.6 mm long. Umbellules 4‒7-flowered. Staminate flowers 3‒6 per umbellule, pedicels ca. 1.5 mm long, petals white, pinkish or bluish purple. Fertile flower 1 per umbellule, sessile; calyx teeth linear to lanceolate, 0.3‒1 mm long; styles 1.5‒5 mm long, sessile, 1.7‒7 times longer than the calyx teeth. Mericarps are oblong-ovoid to ovoid, ca. 2.5 mm long, ca. 2 mm broad, variably spiculate-lamellate, comblike. Vittae 1 under each rib and 2 on commissure.

Distribution and habitat :—
Sanicula lamelligera
is widely distributed in central, eastern, southern, and southwestern China and southern Japan ( Fig. 19 ). It grows in forests on mountain slopes or along ravines and streams at elevations of 450‒1600 m above sea level.
Phenology :—Flowering from late February to June; Fruiting from March to October.

Lectotypification :—
Sanicula orthacantha var. pumila
was described on the basis of two collections, namely P.J. Cavalerie & J.J. Fortunat 1721 and É. Bodinier 2718 . We have been able to trace four specimens of these collections at K and P. All these specimens match well the protologue and are the syntypes as Boissieu (1906) did not designate a type for
S. orthacantha var. pumila
. According to ICN Art. 9.11 (
Turland et al. 2018
), here we designate P03226692 of P.J. Cavalerie & J.J. Fortunat 1721 ( Fig. 4A ), which is well preserved and bears the annotation “
S. orthacantha var. pumila
” in Boissieu’s hand, as lectotype .

Sanicula wakayamensis
was described based on a single collection, namely Y. Syȏzi s.n. We have been able to trace four specimens of this collection at TAI. All these specimens match well the protologue and are the syntypes as Masamune (1941) did not designate type for
S. wakayamensis
. According to ICN Art. 9.11 (
Turland et al. 2018
), here we designate TAI084140 of Y. Syȏzi s.n. ( Fig. 6A ), which is well preserved with intact flowers, as lectotype .

Notes :— Pimenov (2017) designated K000697286 of the single collection, namely T.L. Bullock s.n. ( Herb. Hance 19942 ) ( Fig. 1 A-part), as the lectotype for
S. lamelligera
, which matches the original Latin description perfectly and is well-preserved, so here we accept his lectotypification.

Sanicula tuberculata
was described on the basis of
C. Wilford 906
(GH00589885, K000697277, LE01002000) from Chusan in south Korea ( Maximowicz 1867 ). It is also distributed in China ( Heilongjiang ) and southern Japan ( Sheh & Philleppe 2005). After carefully checking the type material, we found that
S. tuberculata
is distinctly different from
S. lamelligera
by having fertile flowers number 3‒5 per umbellule, and tubercles fruits (vs. fertile flowers number 1 per umbellule, and piculate-lamellate fruits). Thus, we consider the relationship between
S. tuberculata
and
S. lamelligera
is fairly distant, and not so closely related as stated by Hance (1878) and Maximowicz (1887).

Hiroe (1979) placed
Sanicula petagnioides Hayata (1908: 103)
in synonymy with
S. lamelligera
. After checking the type material of
S. petagnioides
, we considered that this name should be treated as a synonym of
S. orthacantha
. We will deal with the identity of
S. petagnioides
in detail elsewhere.

In the protologue of
Sanicula lamelligera
and
S. penghshuiensis
, the authors did not mention the number of vittae in fruit. Hiroe (1979) reported that
S. lamelligera
has 5 vittae, while Sheh & Phillippe (2005) noted that
S. pengshuiensis
has 1 vittae under each rib and 2 vittae on commissure. However, Liu (2002) reported that there are 1 vittae under each rib and 2 vittae on commissure in
S. lamelligera
. Thus,
S. lamelligera
and
S. penghshuiensis
are indistinguishable from each other in the character of vittae.
